In addition, our previous studies demonstrated that ultraviolet B (UVB) irradiation markedly induces phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser10 and Ser28, and the phosphorylation was inhibited by a MEK1 inhibitor or a p38 kinase inhibitor as well as dominant negative mutant ERK or dominant negative mutant p38 kinase in the cells (14.Zhong S.P. Ma W.Y. Dong Z. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 20980-20984Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 15.Zhong S. Jansen C. She Q.B. Goto H. Inagaki M. Bode A.M. Ma W.Y. Dong Z. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 33213-33219Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). These results clearly demonstrated that MAPKs play a key role to phosphorylate histone H3 at Ser10 and Ser28 following stimulation by tumor promoters such as EGF, TPA or UVB. MAPK kinase kinases (MAPKKKs) are a family of serine/threonine protein kinases that can activate one or several of the MAPK kinase/MAPK cascades (16.Robinson M.J. Cobb M.H. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1997; 9: 180-186Crossref PubMed Scopus (2282) Google Scholar). MAPKKKs phosphorylate two serine/threonine residues in the activation/phosphorylation sites of MAPK kinases (17.Yamaguchi K. Shirakabe K. Shibuya H. Irie K. Oishi I. Ueno N. Taniguchi T. Nishida E. Matsumoto K. Science. 1995; 270: 2008-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (1174) Google Scholar). The well known MAPKKKs include the Raf, the MEK kinase (MEKK) and the mixed lineage kinase (MLK) family. The Raf family kinases selectively activate the ERK pathway (18.Wu J. Wong W.W. Khosravi F. Minden M.D. Penn L.Z. Cancer Res. 2004; 64: 6461-6468Crossref PubMed Scopus (202) Google Scholar). On the other hand, MEKK1, MEKK2, and MEKK3 activate both the ERK pathway and the JNK/SAPK pathway (19.Schlesinger T.K. Fanger G.R. Yujiri T. Johnson G.L. Front. Biosci. 1998; 3: D1181-D1186Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). MLK3, MUK, TAK1, and ASK1 activate the JNK/SAPK and p38 kinase pathways (16.Robinson M.J. Cobb M.H. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1997; 9: 180-186Crossref PubMed Scopus (2282) Google Scholar). Some of the MAPKKKs are activated by distinct extracellular stimuli. For example, Raf-1 is activated by mitogens and phorbol esters, TAK1 is activated by transforming growth factor-β and cytokines (17.Yamaguchi K. Shirakabe K. Shibuya H. Irie K. Oishi I. Ueno N. Taniguchi T. Nishida E. Matsumoto K. Science. 1995; 270: 2008-2011Crossref PubMed Scopus (1174) Google Scholar, 20.Shirakabe K. Yamaguchi K. Shibuya H. Irie K. Matsuda S. Moriguchi T. Gotoh Y. Matsumoto K. Nishida E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 8141-8144Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar), and ASK1 is activated by tumor necrosis factor-α (21.Ichijo H. Nishida E. Irie K. ten Dijke P. Saitoh M. Moriguchi T. Takagi M. Matsumoto K. Miyazono K. Gotoh Y. Science. 1997; 275: 90-94Crossref PubMed Scopus (2016) Google Scholar). Very recently, we demonstrated that MLTK-α, a member of the MLK family, induced neoplastic cell transformation and tumorigenesis in athymic nude mice (22.Cho Y.Y. Bode A.M. Mizuno H. Choi B.Y. Choi H.S. Dong Z. Cancer Res. 2004; 64: 3855-3864Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). In addition, MLTK-α translocates into the nucleus after stimulation of EGF or TPA and also induces phosphorylation of c-Myc, Elk-1, c-Jun, and ATF2 (22.Cho Y.Y. Bode A.M. Mizuno H. Choi B.Y. Choi H.S. Dong Z. Cancer Res. 2004; 64: 3855-3864Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). However, even though the role of histone H3 is well characterized in chromatin structure and function, very little is known about the protein kinases that are responsible for the phosphorylation of histones. Here, we demonstrated that MLTK-α is a new kinase that can phosphorylate histone H3 at Ser28, but not Ser10, in vitro and in vivo after stimulation by EGF or UVB. This phosphorylation of histone H3 by MLTK-α may play an important role in chromatin structure remodeling mediating MLTK-α-induced cell transformation or tumorigenesis. Materials—Dulbecco's minimal essential medium (DMEM), Eagle's minimal essential medium (MEM), l-glutamine, gentamicin, and Lipofectamine Plus reagent were purchased from Invitrogen. EGF, PD 98059, and SB 202190 were from Calbiochem-Novabiochem (San Diego, CA), and fetal bovine serum (FBS) was purchased from Gemini Bio-Product (Calabasas, CA). Polyvinylidene difluoride membrane was from Millipore (Bedford, MA), and [γ-32P]ATP and [35S]methionine were purchased from Amersham Biosciences. Pure histone H3, antibodies against histone H3, and phosphorylated H3 (Ser10 and Ser28) were purchased from Upstate Biotechnology Inc., and antibodies against HA and 6xHisG epitopes were from BD Biosciences (Palo Alto, CA) and Invitrogen, respectively. Antibodies against phospho-p90RSK and phospho-MSK1 were from Cell Signaling (Beverly, MA). NE-PER nuclear and cytoplasmic extraction reagent was purchased from Pierce. Construction of Mammalian Expression Vectors—For the mammalian two-hybrid (M2H) system, the cDNAs of 60 human kinases were amplified by PCR and introduced into pBIND two-hybrid system vectors. The cDNA encoding histone H3.3 (a generous gift from Aichi Cancer Center Research Institute, Nagoya, Japan) was recombined into the BamHI/KpnI site of the pACT vector. To produce stably transfected JB6 Cl41 cells, a cDNA fragment from MLTK-α was introduced into the BamHI/KpnI site of pcDNA4-HisMAXA (pHisG-MLTK-α) (Invitrogen). The point mutation of histone H3 at Ser10 (S10A) or Ser28 (S28A) was generated by using the QuikChange II site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) and introduced into the pcDNA3.1/V5-His vector (pV5-H3-S10A or -S28A), respectively. The cDNAs of MLTK-α, MLTK-β, MLTK-α-KM, and MLTK-β-KM cloned into pSRα-HA were kindly provided by Dr. Eisuke Nishida (Kyoto University, Kyoto, Japan). All of the positive clones containing cDNA inserts were confirmed by restriction enzyme mapping and DNA sequence analysis (Genewiz Inc., North Brunswick, NJ). Cell Culture—Swiss 3T3 (Swiss mouse fibroblasts) and 293T (human embryo kidney epithelial) cells were cultured with 10% FBS supplemented with antibiotics. JB6 Cl41 (mouse epithemal) cells were cultured with 5% FBS containing antibiotics. Transfection—The pHisG-MLTK-α stably expressed cells were established using 293T and JB6 Cl41 cells selected by 200 μg/ml of zeocin and pooled. To analyze the interaction of proteins by M2H, 3T3 cells (1.5 × 104) were seeded into 48-well plates and incubated with 10% FBS-DMEM for 18 h before transfection. Transient transfection was carried out using 293T cells to analyze the in vitro kinase activity. The cells were harvested at 48 h of incubation after transfection. Mammalian Two-hybrid Assay—The DNAs, pACT-phistone H3.3, pBIND kinases, and pG5-luciferease, were combined in the same molar ratio, and the total amount of DNA was not more than 100 ng/well. The transfection was performed with Lipofectamine Plus reagent and following the manufacturer's recommended protocols. The cells were disrupted by addition of 200 μl of cell lysis buffer directly into each well of the 48-well plate, and then aliquots of 100 μl were added to each well of a 96-well luminescence plate. The luminescence activity was measured automatically by a computer program from MTX Lab, Inc. (Vienna, VA). The relative luciferase activity was calculated and normalized based on the pG5-luciferase basal control. For assessment of transfection efficiency and protein amount, the luciferase assay, Renilla luciferase activity assay, or Lowry protein assay was used. UVB Irradiation and Chemical Treatment—The JB6 Cl41 overexpressing cells were seeded in 60-mm dishes and cultured in 5% FBS/MEM until they reached 70% confluence and then starved in serum-deprived MEM for 36 h. The cells were then incubated for 2 h in fresh serum-deprived MEM, after which time they were exposed to 4 kJ/m2 UVB and then cultured for an additional 30 min. Because the normal UVB lamp also generates a small amount of UVC light, the UVB irradiation was carried out in a UVB exposure chamber fitted with a Kodak Kodacel K6808 filter that eliminates all wavelengths below 290 nm. For the M2H assay, pBIND kinases and pACT-H3 plasmids were transiently co-transfected in Swiss 3T3 cells. After starvation in serum-deprived DMEM for 24 h, the cells were exposed to 4 kJ/m2 UVB and then cultured for 12 h more. The cells were incubated with 10 ng/ml EGF in culture medium at 37 °C for 30 min or 12 h for the in vivo kinase assay or for the M2H assay, respectively. Isolation of Histone Proteins—Approximately 2 × 107 to 5 × 107 cells were homogenized in 1 ml of nuclear preparation buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.6, 150 mm NaCl, 1.5 mm MgCl2, 0.65% Nonidet P-40, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride) in the presence of protein phosphatase inhibitors (10 mm NaF, 1 mm sodium orthovanadate, 25 mm β-glycerophosphate). The nuclei were recovered by centrifugation at 1500 × g for 10 min at 4 °C and resuspended in 0.3 ml of resuspension buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.6, 3 mm MgCl2, 10 mm NaCl, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and protein phosphatase inhibitors). The nuclei were extracted with 0.4 n H2SO4 to isolate total histones. The samples were precipitated with trichloroacetic acid and then resuspended in double distilled H2O. Immunoblotting—The proteins were resolved by SDS-PAGE and transferred onto polyvinylidene difluoride membranes. The membranes were blocked and then hybridized with the appropriate primary antibody overnight at 4 °C. The protein bands were visualized by a chemiluminescence detection kit (ECL; Amersham Biosciences) after hybridization with the horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody from rabbit or mouse. Immunofluorescence Assay—For translocation of exogenous MLTK-α, the cells were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde, and pHisG-MLTK-α was detected with a monoclonal anti-HisG antibody and a Texas Red-conjugated secondary antibody. Nuclei were stained with 4,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole. The cells were incubated for 24 h, were starved in serum-free medium for an additional 24 h, and then were or were not irradiated with 4kJ/m2 UVB or 10 ng/ml EGF. The samples were analyzed using a fluorescence microscope system (Leica) and Image-Pro software program (Silver Spring). In Vitro Binding Assay—Protein MLTK-α labeled with [35S]methionine was produced by the TnT Quick-coupled transcription/translation system (Promega) using a pHisG-MLTK-α expression vector following the manufacturer's recommended protocols. The 35S-labeled MLTK-α protein was immunoprecipitated using an anti-Xpress antibody and protein A-Sepharose 4B beads (Zymed Laboratory, San Francisco, CA) combined with 4 μg of pure histone H3 protein (Upstate Biotechnology, Inc.) and then incubated 4 h at 4 °C. The beads were washed with buffer (50 mm Tris, pH 7.5, 5 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 0.01% Nonidet P-40, 2 μg/ml bovine serum albumin, 0.2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, protease inhibitor mixture). Following SDS-PAGE and gel drying, the bands were visualized by autoradiography (Kodak, New Haven, CT). Phosphorylation Assay of Histone H3 in Vitro—Phosphorylation of histone H3 by MLTK-α in vitro was carried out as described previously (14.Zhong S.P. Ma W.Y. Dong Z. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 20980-20984Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 23.Huang C. Ma W.Y. Maxiner A. Sun Y. Dong Z. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 12229-12235Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (254) Google Scholar). In brief, the HisG-MLTK-α protein was immunoprecipitated from transiently transfected 293T cells or from the TnT Quick-coupled transcription/translation system, combined with 4 μg of bacterially expressed histone H3 in 50 μl of kinase buffer (20 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 20 mm β-glycerophosphate, 0.1 mm Na3VO4, 10 mm MgCl2, 50 mm NaCl, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 50 μm ATP, 1 mm NaF, and 10 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP) for 1 h at 30 °C. The samples were separated by 15% SDS-PAGE and dried. The [γ-32P]ATP-labeled histone H3 was visualized by autoradiography or by using a phospho-specific antibody against histone H3 (Ser10 or Ser28). Histone H3 Interacts with MLTK-α—Recently, interest has increased in identifying the kinases that modulate chromatin through their mediation of the phosphorylation of histone H3. To identify kinases that interact with histone H3, we used a M2H assay system. In this system, histone H3 was cloned into the pACT expression vector, and individual candidate human protein kinases were cloned into the pBIND expression vector in combination with the pG5 luciferase reporter gene. An interaction between histone H3 and kinases brings together the Gal4-binding domain (from pBIND) and the VP16 transactivation domain (from pACT) of the fusion proteins and activates the luciferase reporter gene in Swiss 3T3 cells. We used the known interaction between histone H3 and DYRK3 as a positive control (pACT-H3/pBIND-DYRK3). DYRK3 is a dual specificity protein kinase that catalyzes phosphorylation on serine/threonine and tyrosine residues and can phosphorylate histone H3 and H2B on serine and threonine residues (24.Becker W. Weber Y. Wetzel K. Eirmbter K. Tejedor F.J. Joost H.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 25893-25902Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (241) Google Scholar). From the results of this assay in which several interesting interactions were found, we confirmed that MLTK-α interacted with histone H3 (Fig. 1A). Fig. 1A shows that more than a 40-fold increase in luciferase activity was observed in MLTK-α and histone H3 co-transfected cells (pACT-H3/pBIND-MLTK-α) compared with only pACT-H3 transfected cells. We next examined the in vitro interaction between MLTK-α and purified histone H3. First, the cDNA coding sequence of MLTK-α or DYRK3 was subcloned into the pcDNA4His/MaxA vector to generate pHisG-MLTK-α or -DYRK3, and the fusion protein was in vitro translated using the TnT Quick-coupled transcription/translation system (Promega). Histone H3 immunoprecipitated with protein A-Sepharose 4B beads was incubated with [35S]methionine-labeled MLTK-α or DYRK3. The bound protein eluted from the beads was separated by SDS-PAGE and then detected by autoradiography. Fig. 1B shows that MLTK-α or DYRK3 efficiently interacted with histone H3 in the in vitro binding assays. Input represents 5% of material used for the in vitro binding assays. MLTK-α Phosphorylates Histone H3 at Ser28 in Vitro—To continue to determine whether histone H3 is a substrate of MLTK-α, we next performed an in vitro kinase assay with histone H3 using MLTK-α-overexpressing 293T cells transfected with the pHisG-MLTK-α. Overexpression of MLTK-α was detected in pHisG-MLTK-α stably transfected cells using an anti-HisG antibody (Fig. 2A). Expression was not detectable in wild type 293T cells or empty (“mock”) vector stably transfected cells. MLTK-α was immunoprecipitated using an anti-Xpress antibody against pHisG-MLTK-α. MLTK-α kinase activity with histone H3 as a substrate was measured at 30 °C at the indicated time points (Fig. 2B). We confirmed that MLTK-α immunoprecipitated from MLTK-α-overexpressing 293T cells significantly phosphorylates histone H3 in a time-dependent manner reaching a peak activity at 60 min (Fig. 2B). We next explored whether MLTK-α-phosphorylation of histone H3 occurred at Ser10 or Ser28. Interestingly, MLTK-α phosphorylated histone H3 only at Ser28 but not at Ser10 (Fig. 2C, second and third panel). To confirm that MLTK-α specifically phosphorylated histone H3 at Ser28, but not Ser10, we replaced Ser10 of histone H3 with alanine (S10A) and Ser28 with alanine (S28A) and then subcloned these constructs into the pcDNA3.1/V5-His vector (Fig. 2D, upper panels). The mutation of histone H3 (Ser28) completely blocked the ability of MLTK-α to phosphorylate H3 compared with wild type H3, whereas the mutation of histone H3 (Ser10) had no effect (Fig. 2D, bottom panels), confirming that Ser28 of histone H3 is the specific MLTK-α phosphorylation site. MLTK-α, but Not MLTK-β, Phosphorylates Histone H3 (Ser28) in Vitro—MLTK-α and MLTK-β were identified by 5′- and 3′-RACE analyses, which showed at least two mRNA variants with different 3′-sequences (25.Gotoh I. Adachi M. Nishida E. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 4276-4286Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). cDNA cloning of the two variants and open reading frame prediction revealed that the two proteins have identical amino acid sequences in the NH2-terminal region (residues 1–311), which contains a kinase domain and a leucine zipper motif. The COOH-terminal region of MLTK-α has a sterile α-motif domain that has been shown to be involved in protein-protein interactions and dimer formation of several signaling molecules and transcription regulators (26.Ponting C.P. Protein Sci. 1995; 4: 1928-1930Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar). We expressed HA-tagged MLTK-α (pHA-MLTK-α) and -MLTK-β (pHA-MLTK-β), or the kinase negative mutants of MLTKs, made by replacing Lys45 with Met (pHA-MLTK-α-KM and -MLTK-β-KM) in Swiss 3T3 cells. We then determined whether either or both of the MLTKs phosphorylated histone H3 in vitro and whether the kinase-negative mutants of the MLTKs blocked the phosphorylation of histone H3 in vitro. After immunoprecipitation with an anti-HA antibody, we analyzed MLTKs kinase activity for the phosphorylation of histone H3 in vitro. Very little phosphorylation of histone H3 was detected in MLTK-α-KM, MLTK-β, or MLTKβ-KM in vitro (Fig. 3, first panel), although a clear phosphorylation of histone H3 was seen in wild type MLTK-α in vitro. Also, the phosphorylation of histone H3 by MLTK-α, but not MLTK-α-KM, MLTK-β, and MLTK-β-TM, was detected with an anti-phospho-histone H3 (Ser28) antibody (Fig. 4B, second panel). Taken together, these results suggest that MLTK-α, but not MLTK-β, can phosphorylate histone H3 at Ser28, and the serine/threonine kinase domain of MLTK-α plays an important role in the phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28.Fig. 4Ser28 phosphorylation of histone H3 occurs in MLTK-α-overexpressing 293T cells but is attenuated in MLTK-α knockdown JB6 Cl41 cells. A, MLTK-α-overexpressing 293T cells were starved for 36 h in serum-deprived DMEM. Ser28 phosphorylation of histone H3 in MLTK-α-overexpressing 293T cells was detected by blotting with an anti-phospho-H3 (Ser28) antibody. Mock denotes a pcDNA4his/MaxA transfected control cell line. Overexpression of MLTK-α was detected in stably transfected 293T cells using an anti-HisG antibody. For visualizing equal loading of protein, total histone H3 was detected by immunoblotting (IB). B, for the gene knock-down experiment, the si-MLTK-α expression vector was constructed using the pmU6pro vector with si-MLTK-α synthetic oligomers. The pmU6pro vector containing siRNA against MLTK-α was transfected into MLTK-α-overexpressing JB6 Cl41 cells, and stable cell lines were established by selection with geneticin (800 μg/ml). Knock-down of MLTK-α in stably transfected pHisG-MLTK-α/si-MLTK-α JB6 Cl41 cells was verified by immunoblotting using an anti-HisG antibody and compared with mock (pcDNA4/hisMaxA) or MLTK-α-overexpressing JB6 Cl41 cells. The cells were cultured and then starved for 36 h and harvested. Alterations of phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28 in mock, pHisG-MLTK-α, or pHisG-MLTK-α/si-MLTK-α cells were detected by immunoblotting using an anti-phospho-H3 (Ser28) antibody. For visualizing equal loading of protein, total histone H3 or β-actin was detected by immunoblotting.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) MLTK-α Plays an Important Role in the Phosphorylation of Histone H3 at Ser28 in Vivo—To study whether MLTK-α regulates the phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28 in vivo, we examined changes in endogenous histone H3 phosphorylation in 36-h serum-starved 293T cells, which stably express the pHisG-MLTK-α. The results demonstrated that overexpression of MLTK-α in 293T cells was accompanied by increased phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28 with serum deprivation (Fig. 4A). We next examined whether the knock-down of the MLTK-α gene by the direct introduction of siRNA against MLTK-α into MLTK-α-overexpressing JB6 Cl41 cells would decrease the phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28 under the 36-h serum starvation conditions. Previously, we developed and confirmed that mRNA and protein levels of MLTK-α were significantly decreased by introducing siRNA MLTK-α into MLTK-α-overexpressing JB6 Cl41 cells (pHisG-MLTK-α/si-MLTK-α) (Fig. 4B, third panel) (22.Cho Y.Y. Bode A.M. Mizuno H. Choi B.Y. Choi H.S. Dong Z. Cancer Res. 2004; 64: 3855-3864Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The results showed that phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28 in pHisG-MLTK-α/si-MLTK-α JB6 Cl41 cells was significantly blocked compared with MLTK-α-overexpressing JB6 Cl41 cells (pHisG-MLTK-α) or even “mock” JB6 Cl41 cells (Fig. 4B, first panel). This finding further confirms that MLTK-α plays an essential role in the phosphorylation of histone H3 at Ser28 in vivo. The Accumulation of HisG-MLTK-α in the Nucleus Was Induced by UVB or EGF Stimulation—MLTK-α contains two putative nuclear export signal-like sequences in the NH2 and COOH termini. MLTK-α is mainly localized in the cytosol and is known to accumulate in the nucleus when cells are treated with leptomycin, an inhibitor of the nuclear export signal receptor, EGF, or TPA (22.Cho Y.Y.
